Testing Swing code can be really painfull so I think it's time for a nice and
meaningfull refactoring!

I always consider my Swing UI as a client to my core application and I
typically develop 2 clients for my core application: a console and a swing
application.  It keeps me from putting too much code in the UI and ease the
testing (the tests are simply considered as yet another client).

I would write a DBAccess class that deals with generating the SQL code (use
PrepareStatement instead of Statement: it's nicer and less error prone) and has
some public methods.  You can now easily test your SQL code and your Swing
interface will hopefully become really easy (and you could skip your testing if
you're confident).

The advantage of this approach is that you can now have different drivers for
different dbs (like an XML db).  And on top of that you can reuse the same
tests to validate all your drivers!  Isn't that a nice solution?

Tip : Constructors can call other constructors:
public AddState(java.awt.Dialog parent, boolean modal, int id_State) {
   this(parent, modal);
   id = id_State;
}
or (I prefer this version)
public AddState(java.awt.Dialog parent, boolean modal) {
   this(parent, modal, NO_STATE);
}
